content.text:
# Draft:Edward van Schoonhoven Kinsley

= Edward van Schoonhoven Kinsley =
Edward van Schoonhoven Kinsley (July 11, 1825 â€“ April 1, 1888) was an American educator, lawyer, and diplomat associated with West Point, New York.
Early Life and Education
Kinsley was born at West Point, New York, the son of Zebina James Duncan Kinsley and Eliza (Van Schoonhoven) Kinsley. He prepared for college under the guidance of Hon. A. N. Skinner in New Haven and his father at West Point. He entered Yale College as a member of the Class of 1846 and graduated with his degree that year.
Career
After completing his studies, Kinsley pursued law and was admitted to the bar at the November General Term of the Supreme Court in New York in 1848. Following the death of his father, with whom he had previously assisted in teaching, he succeeded him as principal of the Classical and Mathematical School at West Point in 1849.
Kinsley later spent nearly a year traveling in Europe, during which he narrowly escaped drowning after falling overboard while returning home. He experienced several family tragedies, including the deaths of his father and four sisters. Two of his sisters perished in the burning of the Henry Clay on the Hudson River in 1851.
Later Life and Diplomatic Service
Kinsley struggled with poor health for several years. In 1867, he traveled to Europe once more, visiting London, Paris, and Madrid. During his stay in Madrid, he became acquainted with the staff of the United States Legation and was warmly received there. On March 7, 1868, he married Lizzie L. Hale, daughter of Hon. John P. Hale, the American Minister to Spain. The ceremony was performed by the chaplain of the British Embassy.
Following their marriage, the couple spent nine months traveling through Spain, Switzerland, Belgium, and France before returning to Madrid. There, Kinsley served as private secretary to the United States Minister and later as Acting Secretary of Legation for several months.
In 1869, he spent several months in Paris, where his son, John Parker Hale Kinsley, was born on October 2. The child was baptized by Rev. Dr. Robinson of the American Chapel but died shortly thereafter and was buried in the cemetery of Antenie.
During the following winter, Kinsley visited Italy and later traveled through Germany before returning to West Point in June 1870. He was known to attend services at the Chapel of the United States Military Academy.
Death
Edward Van Schoonhoven Kinsley died on April 1, 1888. His postal address at the time of his later life was West Point, New York.
